questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GATATC- CTATAG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In RFLP, restriction enzymes recognize and cut at palindromic sequences in DNA. The palindromic sequence GATATC-CTATAG is a correct recognition site for these enzymes, making it crucial for identifying different species, such as staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? ( AIIMS May 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA

options.label: D
options.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: A biochemistry student is studying the various roles of NADPH in cellular metabolism. The student learns that NADPH plays a critical role in providing reducing power for specific biosynthetic reactions. In which of the following biological processes is NADPH primarily utilized?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • NADPH is crucial in fatty acid synthesis, where it acts as a reducing agent that provides the necessary electrons to convert acetyl-CoA into long-chain fatty acids. NADPH donates hydrogen atoms during the reduction steps required to build carbon chains, particularly in the enzymatic actions of ketoacyl-ACP reductase and enoyl-ACP reductase during de novo fatty acid synthesis. The reducing power of NADPH is essential for the synthesis of fatty acids, as it helps convert precursors into fully formed fatty acid molecules.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. DNA replication: DNA replication primarily involves the synthesis of DNA using nucleotides and enzymes such as DNA polymerase. NADPH does not play a direct role in this process, as the reactions are driven by nucleotide triphosphates rather than reduction.
  • • A. DNA replication:
  • • C. Protein degradation: Protein degradation involves the breakdown of proteins into amino acids, mainly facilitated by proteolytic enzymes. This process does not require NADPH, as it involves hydrolysis rather than reduction.
  • • C. Protein degradation:
  • • D. Glycogenolysis: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate and glucose. This process is catalyzed by glycogen phosphorylase and other enzymes, and does not involve NADPH, as it is not a reducing process.
  • • D. Glycogenolysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NADPH is primarily used as a reducing agent in biosynthetic processes, such as fatty acid synthesis, cholesterol synthesis, and the detoxification of reactive oxygen species. It is generated by pathways like the hexose monophosphate shunt and utilized in reactions requiring reduction, underscoring its importance in cellular metabolism and protection against oxidative stress. Understanding NADPH's role in metabolic pathways highlights its critical function in anabolic and protective cellular processes.

questions.text: DNA packing is done by? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Histone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins
  • ➤ Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins
  • ➤ Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO 4 2- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 351

questions.text: What is the order of drawing blood sample in vials/vacutainers: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey.
  • • Different vials or vacutainers are used to collect specific types of blood samples for various laboratory tests. Each color-coded tube is designed to preserve and stabilize specific components of the blood. The correct order mentioned above follows this sequence:
  • • 1. Blue: The blue-top tube is typically used for coagulation tests that require blood to be collected in citrate anticoagulant. The citrate in the tube helps prevent blood clotting by binding calcium.
  • • 1. Blue:
  • • 2. Red: The red-top tube does not contain any anticoagulant and is commonly used for collecting blood samples for various tests, including serum chemistry, blood bank, and serology. After allowing the blood to clot, it is centrifuged, and the resulting serum is used for analysis.
  • • 2. Red:
  • • 3. Lavender: The lavender-top tube contains EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) as an anticoagulant. It is used for collecting whole blood for complete blood count (CBC), blood typing, and other hematological tests. EDTA helps preserve the blood cell morphology.
  • • 3. Lavender:
  • • 4. Grey: The grey-top tube contains an anticoagulant called potassium oxalate or sodium fluoride. It is used primarily for glucose testing and helps preserve blood glucose levels by inhibiting glycolysis.
  • • 4. Grey:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue (coagulation tests), Red (serum tests), Lavender (hematology tests), and Grey (glucose tests) to ensure accurate test results and avoid cross-contamination.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HIV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit? ( INICET May 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

options.label: B
options.text: Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted

options.label: D
options.text: RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only

questions.correct_answer: A. Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hayflick limit describes the finite number of times that normal human cells can divide before they become senescent, primarily due to telomere shortening.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Albinism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.
  • ➤ Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RT-PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RT-PCR is an RNA-based technique that involves reverse transcription of RNA into cDNA followed by PCR amplification, widely used in gene expression analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.
  • • Option A. Liver:
  • • Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.
  • • Option B. Pancreas:
  • • Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.
  • • Option D. Placenta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old researcher is studying various amino acids and their incorporation into proteins during post-translational modifications. During a discussion on how certain amino acids are synthesized and integrated into proteins, he comes across an amino acid that is incorporated directly during translation rather than being formed through post-translational modification. Which of the following amino acids is not produced through post-translational modification?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Selenocysteine, often referred to as the 21st amino acid, is unique because it is directly incorporated into proteins during translation, rather than being formed through post-translational modification. It is encoded by the UGA codon, which usually signals a stop but is recoded to incorporate selenocysteine due to the presence of a specific secondary structure in the mRNA called the Selenocysteine Insertion Sequence (SECIS). The synthesis of selenocysteine involves replacing the oxygen of serine with selenium. It plays a crucial role in the active sites of several enzymes, such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinases, which are important for antioxidant defense and thyroid hormone metabolism.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. N-formylmethionine: N-formylmethionine is a modified form of methionine that serves as the initiator amino acid in bacterial protein synthesis. It is a result of a post-translational modification that adds a formyl group to methionine, unlike selenocysteine which is directly incorporated during translation.
  • • A. N-formylmethionine:
  • • C. γ-Carboxyglutamate: This modified form of glutamate is generated through post-translational carboxylation, which is essential in blood clotting factors to bind calcium ions, a key step in the coagulation cascade.
  • • C. γ-Carboxyglutamate:
  • • D. Phosphoserine: Phosphoserine is formed by the phosphorylation of serine residues in proteins, a common post-translational modification that plays a significant role in regulating protein function, unlike selenocysteine which is directly integrated during protein synthesis.
  • • D. Phosphoserine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selenocysteine is distinct among amino acids as it is incorporated during translation rather than being modified post-translationally. This unique incorporation mechanism highlights its specialized role in the active sites of specific enzymes, emphasizing the critical nature of direct incorporation for its biological functions.

questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • • Option B. Nucleotide excision repair:
  • • Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.
  • • Option C. Base excision repair:
  • • Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.
  • • Option D. Homologous recombinant repair:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 370
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 370

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vit B12

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.
  • ➤ Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 536
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 536

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is used for? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Organ transplantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uses of Chimeric DNA are:
  • ➤ Uses of Chimeric DNA are:
  • ➤ Recombinant human insulin Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH) Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin) Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc. Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.) Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.) Recombinant enzymes (acid α glucosidase [myozyme], α L iduronidase [aldurazyme]) Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing Herbicide and insect resistant crops Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc. Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH). Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations. Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN) Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation
  • ➤ Recombinant human insulin
  • ➤ Recombinant human growth hormone (HGH, somatotropin) and other human hormones (e.g. FSH)
  • ➤ Recombinant blood clotting factor VIII and other clotting factors (Factor IX, tPA, hirudin)
  • ➤ Recombinant hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, etc.
  • ➤ Cytokines and growth factors (interferon, interleukins, etc.)
  • ➤ Monoclonal antibodies and other related products (rituximab, trastuzumab, etc.)
  • ➤ Recombinant enzymes (acid α glucosidase [myozyme], α L iduronidase [aldurazyme])
  • ➤ Recombinant HIV protein for HIV ELISA testing
  • ➤ Herbicide and insect resistant crops
  • ➤ Other products: Bone morphogenic protein (BMP), albumin, fibinolytic and thrombolytic agents, etc.
  • ➤ Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in sit hybridization (FISH).
  • ➤ Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • ➤ Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SN)
  • ➤ Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • ➤ Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.
  • ➤ They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

questions.text: Which of the following has protective as well as lubricating property? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mucin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucins have both protective and lubricating properties, forming a barrier on epithelial surfaces and reducing friction in various body tracts. They are essential for maintaining the integrity and function of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. W Y

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate
  • • transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific
  • • segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.
  • • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5. Promoter W Required for segment 1. Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5. Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5. Promoter W Required for segment 1. Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5. Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Promoter W Required for segment 1. Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5. Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
  • • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
  • • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including
  • • the correct segments and excluding segment 2.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a (W, X, Y) : This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A. Option b (W, Z) : Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A. Option c (WX) : Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.
  • • Option a (W, X, Y) : This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.
  • • Option a (W, X, Y) : This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it
  • • Option a (W, X, Y)
  • • is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.
  • • Option b (W, Z) : Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • • Option b (W, Z)
  • • Option c (WX) : Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.
  • • Option c (WX)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate
  • ➤ transcription of that gene.
  • ➤ Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: What is the primary role of CG islands in our DNA? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • CG islands, also known as CpG islands, are regions rich in cytosine and guanine dinucleotides in which the cytosine residues can be methylated. This methylation process plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression by affecting the accessibility of DNA to transcription machinery, thereby influencing whether genes are active or silenced.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • b. Acetylation : Incorrect because acetylation typically involves histones, not directly the DNA or specific DNA regions like CG islands. c. t-RNA synthesis : Incorrect as t-RNA synthesis is not directly related to CG islands; it generally occurs in the nucleolus and involves RNA polymerase III. d. DNA replication : Incorrect because, while CG islands may influence the overall structure and replication timing of the genome, they are not directly involved in the replication process itself.
  • • b. Acetylation : Incorrect because acetylation typically involves histones, not directly the DNA or specific DNA regions like CG islands.
  • • b. Acetylation
  • • c. t-RNA synthesis : Incorrect as t-RNA synthesis is not directly related to CG islands; it generally occurs in the nucleolus and involves RNA polymerase III.
  • • c. t-RNA synthesis
  • • d. DNA replication : Incorrect because, while CG islands may influence the overall structure and replication timing of the genome, they are not directly involved in the replication process itself.
  • • d. DNA replication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ CG islands are crucial for the methylation of DNA, a key epigenetic mechanism that regulates gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Protein degradation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells . The proteasome assembly has a central cylindrical hollow core. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein into small oligopeptides of 5-6 amino acids length
  • ➤ Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells
  • ➤ Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein
  • ➤ The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins . It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.
  • ➤ proteasome is a cylindrical structure
  • ➤ degrades polyubiquitinated proteins
  • ➤ It plays the major role in the degradation of proteins, and is particularly associated with disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes that have short half-lives.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds to: ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Globin part of Hb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large positive charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated directly or indirectly by? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption. Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.
  • ➤ Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • ➤ Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: All of the following drugs act as HER-1 inhibitors except ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Pertuzumab

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in image below? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Congenital melanocytic nevus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN):
  • ➤ Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN):
  • ➤ Presentation: These nevi are typically pigmented and hairy and may vary in size. The presence of hair is a distinguishing feature that often helps differentiate them from other pigmented lesions. Risk Factors: Larger nevi have a higher risk of developing malignant melanoma later in life, but this is rare with smaller nevi. Management: Monitoring is essential, and in some cases, surgical removal may be considered for aesthetic reasons or to reduce melanoma risk, particularly in larger lesions.
  • ➤ Presentation: These nevi are typically pigmented and hairy and may vary in size. The presence of hair is a distinguishing feature that often helps differentiate them from other pigmented lesions.

  • ➤ Risk Factors:
  • ➤ Management: Monitoring is essential, and in some cases, surgical removal may be considered for aesthetic reasons or to reduce melanoma risk, particularly in larger lesions.

questions.text: Match the characteristics resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome : Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.
  • • Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  • • Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing):
  • • Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  • • Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing):
  • • Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome : Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  • • Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome
  • • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.
  • • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dysgerminoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass with raised LDH points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas usually arise in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. They currently account for approximately one-third of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors and are the most common malignant ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor: This is typically associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), not LDH.
  • • Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor:
  • • Option C. Malignant teratoma: This type of tumor does not typically present with elevated LDH as the sole abnormal marker.
  • • Option C. Malignant teratoma:
  • • Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: This epithelial ovarian tumor is usually associated with elevated CA-125, not LDH.
  • • Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysgerminoma is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with an ovarian mass and elevated LDH levels.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: How is ammonia removed from the brain? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the brain, ammonia is detoxified by being converted into glutamine through the enzyme glutamine synthetase. This process combines glutamate with ammonia, safely encapsulating the ammonia for transport to the liver, where it can be further processed.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Urea : Ammonia is not directly converted into urea in the brain; rather, it is converted into glutamine, which is transported to the liver where urea synthesis occurs. Alanine : While alanine does act as a carrier of ammonia in muscles by transamination reactions, it is not a primary pathway for ammonia removal in the brain. Glutamate : Although glutamate is involved in the initial steps, it is the substrate that accepts ammonia to form glutamine, not the final carrier of ammonia.
  • • Urea : Ammonia is not directly converted into urea in the brain; rather, it is converted into glutamine, which is transported to the liver where urea synthesis occurs.
  • • Urea
  • • Alanine : While alanine does act as a carrier of ammonia in muscles by transamination reactions, it is not a primary pathway for ammonia removal in the brain.
  • • Alanine
  • • Glutamate : Although glutamate is involved in the initial steps, it is the substrate that accepts ammonia to form glutamine, not the final carrier of ammonia.
  • • Glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Glutamine acts as a non-toxic carrier of ammonia from the brain to the liver, where ammonia is further processed into urea, showcasing the brain's indirect participation in the urea cycle.

questions.text: The loading dose of MgSo4 in pre-eclampsia is? (INICET NOV 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: 4 ml Mgso4 (50% w/v) in 16 ml NS

options.label: B
options.text: 8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS

options.label: C
options.text: 12 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 8 ml NS

questions.correct_answer: B. 8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 8 ml MgSo4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The drug of choice for the management of eclampsia is Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4). The most commonly used regimen in India is the Pritchard regimen, which involves an initial loading dose followed by maintenance doses.
  • • For the loading dose, the Pritchard regimen recommends:
  • • Loading dose: 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously at 1 gram per minute. Additionally, 10 grams of 50% MgSO4 is administered intramuscularly, with 5 grams in each buttock.
  • • Loading dose: 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously at 1 gram per minute.
  • • Loading dose:
  • • Additionally, 10 grams of 50% MgSO4 is administered intramuscularly, with 5 grams in each buttock.
  • • In this question, option B, "8 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS," correctly refers to the preparation required to administer the initial dose of MgSO4.
  • • The preparation details:
  • • MgSO4 is available in 50% and 20% concentrations. To make a 50% MgSO4 solution into a 20% solution, a 1.5 times dilution is required. For a 50% MgSO4 solution, 1 ml of the solution contains 0.5 grams of MgSO4 (1 ampoule = 2 ml).
  • • MgSO4 is available in 50% and 20% concentrations.
  • • To make a 50% MgSO4 solution into a 20% solution, a 1.5 times dilution is required.
  • • For a 50% MgSO4 solution, 1 ml of the solution contains 0.5 grams of MgSO4 (1 ampoule = 2 ml).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The loading dose of MgSO4 in pre-eclampsia, as per the Pritchard regimen, is 4 grams of MgSO4 as a 20% solution administered intravenously, often prepared using 8 ml of 50% MgSO4 diluted in 12 ml normal saline.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg273, Williams textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 1840
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg273, Williams textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 1840

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertriglyceridemia is being considered for niacin therapy to help control her lipid levels. She also has well-controlled type 2 diabetes, managed with metformin and lifestyle modifications. Given her diabetic status, her physician is concerned about potential side effects associated with niacin use. Why should niacin be used with caution in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Niacin therapy, while effective in lowering triglycerides and improving lipid profiles, is associated with a risk of increasing blood glucose levels. Niacin can induce insulin resistance and reduce glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, potentially leading to hyperglycemia. This effect is particularly concerning in patients with diabetes, even those with well-controlled blood sugar levels. Therefore, niacin should be used cautiously in diabetic patients, and their blood glucose should be monitored closely, especially in the initial weeks of therapy to ensure that blood sugar levels remain within a safe range.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Risk of hypotension: Niacin does not typically cause hypotension. It can cause vasodilation and flushing but does not significantly lower blood pressure to a concerning degree, especially not enough to be the primary caution in diabetic patients.
  • • A. Risk of hypotension:
  • • B. Increased risk of liver toxicity: Although niacin can cause hepatotoxicity, particularly at high doses, this effect is not specific to diabetic patients and does not directly impact glucose control. Liver function should still be monitored, but it is not the primary concern when considering niacin in a diabetic patient.
  • • B. Increased risk of liver toxicity:
  • • D. Risk of severe muscle cramps: Muscle cramps are more commonly associated with statin use rather than niacin. Niacin does not directly contribute to myopathy or muscle cramps and thus is not a specific concern in this scenario.
  • • D. Risk of severe muscle cramps:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niacin can cause an increase in blood sugar levels due to insulin resistance and reduced glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, making its use risky in diabetic patients. Caution and close monitoring of blood glucose levels are necessary when prescribing niacin to individuals with diabetes, particularly those who have well-controlled blood sugar levels, to prevent hyperglycemia and ensure safe therapy.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? ( NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients

options.label: B
options.text: Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur

options.label: D
options.text: Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.correct_answer: B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.
  • • Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients:
  • • Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.
  • • Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur:
  • • Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.
  • • Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text: Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? (INICET MAY 2022) Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The true statements are:
  • • Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers provide widespread distribution throughout the body, innervating various organs and tissues. In contrast, parasympathetic fibers have a more restricted distribution, primarily targeting the head, neck, and trunk regions.
  • • Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  • • Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. Motor neurons originate in the ventral horn of the spinal cord, and their axons branch out to innervate individual muscle fibers, facilitating voluntary muscle movements.
  • • Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Statement 2: Incorrect. Sympathetic fibers do not travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain before synapsing. Instead, sympathetic preganglionic fibers travel a short distance to the ganglia (which are located close to the spinal cord) and then the postganglionic fibers travel a long distance to reach the effector organs.
  • • Statement 2:
  • • Statement 3: Incorrect. Parasympathetic fibers travel a long distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to or within the target organs.
  • • Statement 3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head neck and trunk

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of prolonged fasting is admitted to the hospital with fatigue and dizziness. Laboratory tests reveal low blood glucose levels, despite her attempts to consume protein-rich food. The medical team suspects a metabolic disorder affecting glucose synthesis. Which enzyme plays a crucial role in the patient's ability to produce glucose during fasting?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pyruvate Carboxylase is a key enzyme in gluconeogenesis that catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate. This reaction is essential for gluconeogenesis, which allows the body to generate glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates such as amino acids and lactate during fasting or starvation. The enzyme plays a critical role in bypassing the irreversible steps of glycolysis, permitting glucose synthesis when dietary intake is low.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • B. Phosphofructokinase-1: This enzyme is primarily involved in glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis. It converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, playing a regulatory role in glycolysis.
  • • B. Phosphofructokinase-1:
  • • C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the glycolytic pathway and catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It does not function in gluconeogenesis.
  • • C. Hexokinase:
  • • D. Glucokinase: Similar to hexokinase, glucokinase is involved in glycolysis, especially in the liver, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is not part of the gluconeogenic pathway.
  • • D. Glucokinase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gluconeogenesis is critical for maintaining blood glucose levels during periods of fasting. Key enzymes like pyruvate carboxylase facilitate the conversion of non-carbohydrate sources into glucose, enabling the body to sustain energy levels when dietary glucose is unavailable.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a background of metabolic research is studying an enzyme-catalyzed reaction in his laboratory. He plots the reaction velocity against substrate concentration and observes the curve shown in the graph below. What type of kinetic pattern is most likely being depicted in the graph?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The graph depicts a classic Michaelis-Menten kinetic pattern characterized by a hyperbolic relationship between reaction velocity and substrate concentration. Michaelis-Menten kinetics describes enzyme activity where the reaction velocity increases with substrate concentration but eventually plateaus as the enzyme becomes saturated with substrate. The key points of Michaelis-Menten kinetics include Vmax, the maximum reaction velocity when the enzyme is fully saturated, and Km, the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of Vmax. This kinetic model is typical for enzymes that follow simple substrate binding and catalysis without significant allosteric or cooperative interactions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Competitive Inhibition: In competitive inhibition, an inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme, which can be overcome by increasing substrate concentration. The graph of competitive inhibition would show an increase in Km without altering Vmax, which differs from the hyperbolic curve seen in Michaelis-Menten kinetics.
  • • A. Competitive Inhibition:
  • • B. Non-competitive Inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, reducing the overall number of active enzymes. This type of inhibition lowers Vmax without affecting Km, resulting in a different pattern from the Michaelis-Menten kinetics shown in the graph.
  • • B. Non-competitive Inhibition:
  • • D. Allosteric Regulation: Allosteric enzymes exhibit sigmoidal curves rather than hyperbolic curves due to cooperative substrate binding. These enzymes are regulated by effectors that alter their activity, making their kinetics distinct from the Michaelis-Menten kinetics depicted in the graph.
  • • D. Allosteric Regulation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Michaelis-Menten kinetics describes enzyme behavior where reaction velocity increases with substrate concentration but reaches a plateau at high substrate levels due to enzyme saturation. Key features include Vmax and Km, which help determine the efficiency and affinity of enzyme-substrate interactions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is found to have a fibroid of 14 weeks size. She has no specific symptoms. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.correct_answer: C. No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the case of an asymptomatic fibroid, intervention is generally not required regardless of the size. The management approach is typically conservative, involving observation and regular monitoring.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop. Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass. Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.
  • • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop.
  • • Asymptomatic Fibroids:
  • • Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass.
  • • Common Symptoms of Fibroids:
  • • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.
  • • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a major surgical procedure and is typically reserved for symptomatic fibroids or when other treatment options have failed or are not suitable.
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy:
  • • Option B. Myomectomy: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids and is considered for symptomatic patients who wish to preserve their uterus.
  • • Option B. Myomectomy:
  • • Option D. Medical management: Medical management is used to manage symptoms and is not necessary for asymptomatic fibroids.
  • • Option D. Medical management:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In asymptomatic patients with fibroids, intervention is generally not required. Observation and regular monitoring are appropriate unless symptoms develop, in which case, further management options such as myomectomy or hysterectomy may be considered.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg207
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg207

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Early-onset preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Early-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia. Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers. Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA. Predictors of Preeclampsia: History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors. Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators. Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA. Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Early-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia. Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers. Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • • Early-onset preeclampsia:
  • • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia. Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers. Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia.
  • • Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers.
  • • Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • • Predictors of Preeclampsia: History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors. Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators. Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA. Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Predictors of Preeclampsia:
  • • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors. Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators. Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA. Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
  • • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP):
  • • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
  • • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
  • • Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
  • • Biophysical Markers:
  • • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
  • • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
  • • Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
  • • Biochemical Markers:
  • • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
  • • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF.
  • • Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
  • • Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Anti-angiogenic Factors:
  • • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler is more predictive of early-onset rather than late-onset preeclampsia.
  • • Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia:
  • • Option C. Fetal growth restriction: While fetal growth restriction can be associated with preeclampsia, the uterine artery Doppler specifically predicts early-onset preeclampsia rather than fetal growth restriction alone.
  • • Option C. Fetal growth restriction:
  • • Option D. Placenta accreta: Uterine artery Doppler is not used to detect placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is typically diagnosed through ultrasound or MRI.
  • • Option D. Placenta accreta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks gestation can predict early-onset preeclampsia by identifying raised pulsatility index (PI) and notching of the uterine artery waveform.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Congenital syphilis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kassowitz's rule pertains to congenital syphilis. According to this rule, if a woman with untreated syphilis has multiple pregnancies, the likelihood of congenital syphilis affecting the fetus in later pregnancies decreases. This phenomenon is observed as a result of the immune system's adaptive response and potential changes in the transmission dynamics of the infection over successive pregnancies. Therefore, the rule suggests that with each subsequent pregnancy, the outcome for the fetus improves if the infection remains untreated.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Primary syphilis : Primary syphilis involves the initial chancre or ulcer at the site of infection and is not related to Kassowitz's rule, which specifically addresses outcomes in congenital syphilis.
  • • Option A. Primary syphilis
  • • Option C. Secondary syphilis : Secondary syphilis is characterized by systemic manifestations such as skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions and is not related to Kassowitz's rule.
  • • Option C. Secondary syphilis
  • • Option D. Latent syphilis : Latent syphilis refers to a stage where no symptoms are present but the infection is still systemic. Kassowitz's rule is not associated with latent syphilis.
  • • Option D. Latent syphilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kassowitz rule states that the likelihood of congenital syphilis infection decreases with each successive pregnancy in a woman with untreated syphilis.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 343, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 343, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a recent type B aortic dissection presents with abdominal pain and lower limb ischemia with diminished femoral and popliteal pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Repair the descending aorta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat: Although used for blood pressure control, it doesn't address the underlying issue of malperfusion.
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat:
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside: May help with blood pressure control but doesn't solve the urgent need for revascularization.
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside:
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine: Not appropriate in an acute setting requiring immediate intervention.
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the signs of complicated type B aortic dissection (malperfusion syndromes) and the need for immediate surgical/endovascular repair.

questions.text: For the given Kaplan-Meier curve on the role of T-cells in the allograft rejection process, true statement is: ( INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Only CD4 contributed to graft rejection significantly

options.label: B
options.text: Only CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

options.label: C
options.text: Both CD4 and CD8 protected against graft rejection significantly

options.label: D
options.text: Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

questions.correct_answer: D. Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both CD4 and CD8 T-cells are crucial contributors to the allograft rejection process, and their combined depletion significantly prolongs graft survival.
